prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 6 survey of Cha II (The GASPS sample)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
A band survey for the continuum and 3 CO isotopologues in 30 CTTS of the 4Myr old Chamaeleon II association.
The goal is to study the dispersiuon of dust AND gas and compare with younger (older) associations.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We wish to obtain band 6 continuum and line observations toward 30 targets. We will use the widest bandwidth, 2.0 GHz in 2 spectral windows for an aggregate total of 4.1GHz, for the best continuum sensitivity.
The CO emission comes predominantly from the slowly rotating,outer parts of the disk and the linewidths are typically in the range 15 km/s FWHM. We have set the spectral resolution to 0.3km/sec per channel. The very narrowest lines may be slightly spectrally unresolved but we will be able to measure the integrated line intensity to high sensitivity in all cases. Further, an independent check of two-channel (single velocity resolution) detections is possible by comparing the two polarizations.
Fortunately, Chamaeleon II is a quiescent cloud with a well determined systemic velocity of 3km/s and narrow linewidth of 1.7km/s (Mizuno et al. 2001). Based on our experience with disk observations in Taurus, the disk velocities are expected to be within a few km/s of the cloud velocity and we are confident that the disk emission will lie within the bandpass (with room to spare) in all cases.
Our desired (gas+dust)mass sensitivity of 0.1 MJup corresponds to a flux,F230 GHz = 0.5 mJy at the 178pc distance of Chamaeleon II for an assumed gas-to-dust ratio of 100 and full radiative transfer calculation with MCFOST. The grain opacity used is standard. prescription. We can achieve a robust 5 detection (0.1mJy/beam) in about 3 minutes per target in third octile weather conditions, selected automatically by the OT tool We have chosen this level of significance over the more typical 3 due to the snapshot nature of the integrations and consequent under-sampling of the Fourier plane. Figure 3 shows a simulation of a 3 minute Cycle 2 intermediate array configuration (C34-5) integration of a disk with total flux 1.0 mJy and diameter 300AU at = 77. The disk is clearly detected and the flux is accurately measured but a shorter integration for a nominal 3 detection produces an unreliable result.The corresponding rms is 6 mJy for a 5 km/s wide line and 10 mJy for two channels (0.3km/sec per channel). We can clearly detect the saturated lines and anticipate that we can detect C18O in a median model MMSN disk and 13CO line in disks lower in mass by an order of magnitude (see Fig 3 for 12CO). If no lines are detected, we can place very stringent constraints on the gas mass, ~104 M = 0.1 MJup. An additional crucial advantage of these interferometric observations is that they filter out large scale cloud emission, as our SMA observations of Taurus disks demonstrate. We are principally interested in measuring the total flux but information on the disk size helps narrow down the range of models for estimating gas masses. Thus, although we could achieve our science goals with a more compact configuration, we prefer an intermediate array observations. Resolved disks with sizes > 2.0" = 350 AU will have lower fluxes on longer baselines but are probably more massive and thus easier to detect.. The sources are far enough away from each other to each require an individual pointing but close enough ( < 10 deg) to share the same gain calibrator. The full program can be carried out in a single 3.0-hour track with all targets above 30 elevation and minimal shadowing.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Dust in Protoplanetary disks dissipates with typical timescales of ~3 Myr. By 10Myr, very few disks are detected and little primordial material is left. The formation of gaseous planets must be complete by then. However, this is based almost entirely on measurements of the continuum, of dust, and it assumes that the gas dissipates on the same timescale. Very little information is available regarding the gas dispersal timescale. The Cha II association has an estimated age of about 3-4Myr. The disk detection rate in Cha II, as seen by continuum, is down to ~50% for KM stars making Cha II a perfect place to study disk evolution at the critical time when they evolve rapidly. For comparison the same fraction is ~80% in the 1-2Myr Taurus and Rho Oph.
We propose to survey all known K&M stars with disks of the Chamaeleon II association to measure the band 6 continuum and resolve the disk sizes. We also propose to observe three CO isotopologues to search for the presence cold gas. The sample is carefully selected in stellar mass and will be readily comparable, including gas for the first time,with younger associations with minimum biases.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
